Inference: Soil moisture rising during rain detections, weather-based irrigation reductions, and low water usage indicates strong rainfall replacement
Description: Natural rainfall fully compensates for reduced irrigation, allowing soil moisture to increase without added water.
short rationale: Rain replaces irrigation; minimal sensitivity.

Inference: Soil moisture falling during rain detections, weather-based reductions, and low water usage indicates rainfall too weak to offset moisture loss
Description: The system correctly reduces irrigation for rain, but rainfall is insufficient to maintain soil water levels.
short rationale: Weak rain after reductions; low privacy impact.

Inference: Soil moisture rising when weather-based increases and high water usage occur during no-rain periods indicates effective irrigation under dry conditions
Description: The system responds to dryness and irrigation successfully raises soil moisture.
short rationale: Irrigation effective in dry gaps; low sensitivity.

Inference: Soil moisture falling despite weather-based increases, rising water usage, and no rain detections indicates extreme drought or poor infiltration
Description: Even high irrigation cannot restore soil moisture due to harsh environmental or soil limitations.
short rationale: Severe drought/infiltration failure despite high inputs.

Inference: Soil moisture rising during rain detections even when weather-based increases and high water usage overlap indicates irrigation overriding rainfall impact
Description: The system waters despite rain, causing compounded soil moisture gains.
short rationale: Overlap rain + irrigation raising moisture; modest sensitivity.

Inference: Soil moisture stable during rain detections, weather-based reductions, and zero water usage indicates moderate rainfall insufficient to hydrate soil deeply
Description: Rain moistens the surface but does not penetrate far enough to affect sensor readings.
short rationale: Shallow rain with no irrigation; low privacy risk.

Inference: Water usage rising when weather-based increases and no rain detections occur while soil moisture falls indicates strong atmospheric drying
Description: The system compensates for absent rainfall and ongoing moisture loss by increasing irrigation.
short rationale: Atmospheric drying driving usage; low sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage falling when weather-based reductions and rain detections coincide while soil moisture rises indicates optimal system behavior
Description: Rainfall takes over hydration so irrigation decreases while soil moisture improves.
short rationale: Optimal rain-driven suppression; minimal sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage staying high during rain detections and weather reductions with soil moisture falling indicates irrigation system malfunction
Description: The system does not reduce watering correctly despite rain, and moisture still declines.
short rationale: Malfunction/override keeping high use in rain.

Inference: Soil moisture rising slowly during long rain detection periods despite weather reductions and low water usage indicates sustained light rainfall
Description: Small but continuous rainfall gradually increases soil moisture.
short rationale: Light sustained rain raising moisture; very low sensitivity.

Inference: Soil moisture rising quickly during rain detections and low water usage with weather reductions indicates heavy storm activity
Description: Strong rainfall rapidly hydrates soil without requiring irrigation.
short rationale: Heavy storm hydration; minimal sensitivity.

Inference: Soil moisture falling rapidly during no rain detections and stable water usage despite weather-based increases indicates inadequate irrigation capacity
Description: The system attempts to increase watering but cannot keep up with moisture loss.
short rationale: Capacity shortfall under dryness.

Inference: Soil moisture stable while water usage fluctuates and rain detections occur intermittently indicates soil buffering and saturation equilibrium
Description: The soil holds consistent moisture regardless of watering or rainfall variation.
short rationale: Buffered/saturated soil; very low sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage dropping sharply before rain detections and soil moisture rising indicates accurate forecast-based irrigation reductions
Description: The system anticipates rainfall and reduces irrigation in advance.
short rationale: Accurate forecast reductions; minimal sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage rising before long dry periods with soil moisture falling and no rain detections indicates effective drought preparation
Description: Irrigation increases early to counter upcoming dryness.
short rationale: Pre-drought irrigation increase; low privacy risk.

Inference: Weather-based reductions with rising soil moisture, falling water usage, and multiple rain detections indicate ideal wet-season suppression
Description: Rain events naturally hydrate soil, reducing the need for irrigation.
short rationale: Wet-season suppression; very low sensitivity.

Inference: Weather-based increases with falling soil moisture, rising water usage, and long rain gaps indicate strong seasonal dryness
Description: Absence of rainfall forces irrigation demand upward to counter soil moisture decline.
short rationale: Seasonal dryness response; low sensitivity.

Inference: Soil moisture dropping despite rain detections, weather reductions, and stable water usage indicates rainfall not reaching root zone
Description: Shallow rainfall or canopy effects prevent water from reaching deeper soil layers.
short rationale: Rain not reaching roots; modest operational detail.

Inference: Soil moisture rising during weather-based increases and high water usage despite no rain detections indicates irrigation-driven hydration phase
Description: The system increases watering in dry periods and the soil moisture responds accordingly.
short rationale: Irrigation-driven gains in dry periods; low privacy risk.

Inference: Water usage near-zero during rain detections, low temperatures, and weather reductions while soil moisture rises indicates optimal rainfall integration
Description: The system avoids unnecessary irrigation as rainfall and cool conditions support soil hydration.
short rationale: Optimal integration of cool rain; minimal sensitivity.
